What this child needs most is a sense of permanence and stability, not the foreboding of yet another [presumably] upheaval in his life. I admit to having very mixed feelings about the messages being given to BlueJay as described in this piece. The statements being imparted to him make it sound as if an adoption has already taken place. The situation is far more nuanced than that, no? And while we can question the ability of a three-year-old to undersand nuance, three-years-olds can understand a lot. I wish more of the reality of the actual situation had been conveyed to him. It might be overwhelmingly confusing, and actually traumatic, to him if he does eventually go back to his Mom. I think it would have been more appropriate to describe a version of events in which 1. the actual uncertainty of the situation is honestly acknowledged; 2. the first mother is not obliterated from the narrative.

What you tell kids in situations like this is of paramount importance. It seems more than anything else that the author is prepping BlueJay for irrevocable separaton from his mother. This sets off alarm bells for me.

Also, I need to mention his reactions when you leave the house for 15 minutes. He may have fairly intense separation anxiety. Normal in situations like this.

Say denominations are divisible if each value evenly divides the next largest value. What Hans has referred to as the greedy algorithm shows that for divisible denominations tidy and minimal-count decompositions are equivalent to each other and unique for any given total amount. Abigail has pointed out that when the denominations aren’t divisible, tidy and minimal-count decompositions needn’t coincide. Nor need they be unique. For instance, if the denominations are {1, 2, 3}, 4 decomposes into 1+3 or 2+2, and both decompositions are tidy and minimal-count.

As long as the amounts before and after the transaction both have unique minimal-count decompositions, the answer to Abigail’s question is that the old strategy applies. If, however, the decompositions aren’t unique, the issue isn’t so much whether the strategy applies as whether the problem needs to be reformulated to accommodate multiple possible answers.

Following up on the line of thought started by Abigail, I wonder if anyone knows which sets of denominations (in addition to divisible denominations) admit only unique minimal-count decompositions.

The China crash has echoes of the 2000-2001 bursting of the dot-com bubble, but with an important distinction. Bubbles almost always begin with an element of truth, which then gets blown far out of proportion.  In the dot-com days the element of truth was that the new internet technology was deeply transformative and was unleashing vast productivity efficiencies and wealth creation.  Now, let's look at China. The economy, while ostensibly growing, is on a steady decline in growth.  Without the tumble in commodity prices last quarter's growth would have been about 6% y.o.y., far below target.  The reality is probably half that number once you remove all of the book-cooking.  In general, the economy is not in good shape.  So, the seed of of China's stock market bubble is simply that the CCP leadership wants a higher stock market.  The belief, up until a few weeks ago, was that the CCP could effect this without end.  Corruption, fraud, and cooked books are rampant in China, so in an economy like that you would expect to have a much lower P/E multiple on the market than in transparent markets with better governance.  So, if the US S&P 500 has a ttm P/E multiple of 20 (granted, on the high side), in relative terms what would I be willing to pay for China's market?  Maybe a P/E of 15.  The problem is that even after the recent decline, the P/E on the Chinese market sits at about 50.  Fair value, to me, looks like it starts with a 1 handle on the Shanghai Composite.

@Matthew in Tenn - your 1st paragraph suggests that black people have no agency, that they have just been pawns who were drag-netted from the south to work in the north. I suggest that you read up on the great migrations, which were movements by black populations which they themselves initiated because there was a perceived lack of opportunity in the south compared to the north.

As to your suggestion that the black loss of wealth in 2008 was Obama's fault, that is utter nonsense. It is true that they suffered far more with the recession, in part because more of their total wealth was in their housing, but Mr. Obama did not create the economic mess he was handed in Jan 2009. It is also worth noting that every attempt to improve the lot of the underclass is undermined by the GOP either as a Dem attempt to get more voter loyalty ('give em gov't money and they'll vote for you') or as an unfair granting of special privileges or as a move to take from "hard working real Americans" to give to the unmotivated, lazy poor.

Recent books about the historical development of public housing, about enforced segregation in Norther cities (our most segregated cities are Milwaukee, Philadelphia, and Chicago), and the Pulitzer-winning Slavery By Another Name powerfully undermine the narrative that Black people became free after the Civil War and have failed to get ahead because of some innate inferiority--they continued to be exploited, rounded up (thoughout the south for Northern corporations like US Steel), rented as prison labor. . . kept from the fruits of their labors or access to opportunities right to this very day, if we count the way the power structure in cities like Ferguson and the prison-industrial complex exploit them (viz. the cost of phone calling in the nation's jails and prisons). It's a pitiful, murderous, and evil story, and it has no apparent end.

Half of the black middle class has fallen into poverty since 2008, but this is, in my awareness, the sole real move that Obama has made on specific behalf of his most devoted constituency--who like many took the color of his skin as some promise of far, far better--unobjectionable to all but the most virulently racist among us though it may be. For his allegiance to the wealthy and Wall Street over this country's millions in need he will, one hopes, one day have to answer to a higher authority.

But, the police department is problematic. It has had much lower salaries than surrounding jurisdictions; turnover is high--officers move to counties with less crime and better pay. There s a high percentage of officers with < 5 years experience. The force is 50% black; both white and black officers can be abusive. Three of the six officers arrested in the Freddie Gray death are African American. Batts was in a no-win situation with the riots. The mayor wanted a hands off response and was too late declaring an emergency.

I think officers in many jurisdictions, not just Baltimore, hold back--consciously or unconsciously. But violence is out of control. The article says the three murders in one night were in West Baltimore but they were actually by the U of Baltimore campus just after 10 p.m..

Batts had to go; public and officers lost faith; I fault the mayor too.

Yes lots of loud accusations aimed at one party to the loans, but almost zero to the other.  The deals were cut by governments and banks and both had responsibility to make sure they were good loans.  Since they weren't, the banksters must accept that they made a very poor investment because they failed in their due diligence despite having oodles of financial analysts on staff.  It is starting to appear as if Germany is starting the Fourth Reich, this time the weapons are economic.  EU bought up a lot of these bad bank loans to keep the banksters whole and then Merkel and Schauble have decided to seek their pound of flesh from Greek citizens who had zero to do with these loans, anymore than I set up Gitmo after The Supremes anointed Shrub II.

And the longer this dance goes on, the worse it will become for the so-called European Union.  Merkel needs a wake-up call.
